chapter.title: CLL 第8章Chapter 8 Relative Clauses, Which Make sumti Even More Complicated

section.title: What are you pointing at?
section.paragraph: Let us think about the problem of コミュニケーション communicating what it is that we are pointing at something. In Lojban, we can refer to what we are pointing at by using the pro-sumti ``ti" if it is nearby, or ``ta" if it is somewhat further away, or ``tu" if it is distant. (Pro-sumti are explained in full in Chapter7./chapter7.html.)

However, even with the assistance of a pointing finger, or pointing lips, or whatever may be appropriate in the local culture, it is often hard for a listener to tell just what is being pointed at. Suppose one is pointing at a person (in particular, in the direction of his or her face), and says: 1.1 ti cu barda これは大きい。 This-one is-big.
What is the referent of ``ti"? Is it the person? Or perhaps it is the person's nose? Or even (for ``ti" can be plural as well as singular, and mean "these ones" as well as ``this one") the pores on the person's nose? ページ内リンクのテスト1.1#1.1。
To help solve this problem, Lojban uses a construction called a ``relative clause".
